para.text: On the server side, the Web Viewer application consists of web pages hosted in IIS, and a separate service application. Because there is essentially an ImageViewer in memory for each user session, memory usage and CPU load can get high very quickly. For this reason, the more powerful your servers are, the better, but you should scale these recommendations based on the number of concurrent users you expect to have at any given time.

para.text: In a load-balanced environment, the more machines you have for the same number of concurrent users, the less powerful each machine needs to be. Again, you will need to determine the number of concurrent users you expect to have at any given time. If you are using a load balancer, it must provide client affinity (sticky connections) because a given user's session is kept in memory on one server in the farm; therefore, all communication from a given client must be routed to that machine. Ideally, the load balancer will also be capable of distributing the load equally amongst servers in the farm, so no single server is taxed with too many active, concurrent sessions.
